text: as the UK enters its fourth week in
lockdown ministers are reviewing the
measures imposed to try to curb the
spread of coronavirus another 717 people
have died of the virus in the UK
bringing the total number of deaths in
the country to eleven thousand three
hundred and twenty nine and there are
now nearly 90,000 confirmed cases of
coronavirus on the lockdown
Scotland's First Minister Nicola
Sturgeon has said that while there are
optimistic signs that it's working until
there's solid evidence is unlikely that
restrictions will be lifted it comes as
one of the European countries worst hit
by the pandemics Spain relaxes some of
the restrictions it announced last month
allowing manufacturing and construction
workers to return and an NHS boss has
warned that the number of protective
gowns available to front-line NHS staff
in parts of the UK has become critically
low in recent days well our health
correspondent catherine de costa is here
with me Catherine another very miserable
number again today at the number of
people who've died of coronaviruses in
the last 24 hours
717 but we look don't we every day every
week at the trends in terms of the
number of deaths and cases are how do
you read this yeah that's right because
often you see a lag in delay of
reporting deaths over weekends we saw
that last weekend and obviously with
this being the bank holiday for Day
weekend that also could be the case we
had seen numbers doubling every three
and a half days up to last weekend and
if if that trend had continued we could
have seen as many as 3000 deaths today
now obviously that didn't happen we've
seen as you say an increase of 717 so
it's important not just to read too much
into daily figures you have to look at
the trends and figures have have started
to stabilize there have been fools in
Wales Scotland Northern Ireland just a
small increase in England as I say that
could be down to weekend reporting
delays we'll have to see how the week
progresses
but what what's interesting is that this
week could be crucial because we're
starting to see new cases stabilized and
hospital admissions and the hope is that
that will then feed into a fall in the
number of deaths and the hope is that
we're approaching the peak but experts
are still warning that this is very much
a marathon and not a sprint we should
bear in mind that these figures are of
hospital deaths and we get weekly
figures that include those that happen
in the community and also in care homes
and in the last few minutes Catherine
we've heard news some very sad news of a
number of deaths that have occurred in a
care home yes that's right so we've
heard that 13 residents have now died at
a care home in County Durham this was at
Stanley Park care home and the regional
director of care UK has said that
they're deeply saddened by what's
happened that they are trying to
reassure relatives that they're doing
everything that they can to keep the
residents safe the first case had been
reported in March when a resident died
in hospital they've been the resident to
be living at the care home they had
symptoms that indicate kovat 19 because
this this individual hadn't actually
been tested but it brings the total
there to 13 and we know that the
government is is keeping the lockdown
under review and we are expecting
something later in the week about where
we stand in terms of the lockdown any
potential easing of restrictions but
most people don't think there'll be much
change yeah I mean we were obviously
that today marks three weeks of the
current lockdown we're now going into
the fourth week there will be a meeting
of saige that's a scientific advisory
group for emergencies that will happen
tomorrow and the UK government has until
Thursday to review the restrictions but
the Welsh Government and the Scottish
Government have already said that
they're likely to extend the the
restrictions for several more weeks and
the UK governments together have said
that they will stick together on this so
we're not expecting that the
restrictions will be eased anytime soon
okay Catherine many thanks our health
correspondent Catherine de Costa there
